subject: linear_algebra
title: Basis and Dimension
contentHtml:
A basis in a vector space is a set of vectors that span the entire space without redundancy.

Think of it like a coordinate system: you can represent every point using a combination of these fundamental directions.
intuition: A basis helps us understand the structure of our vector space. It's like having a set of building blocks to construct any vector.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, we often work with high-dimensional spaces and need to find meaningful directions (bases) for dimensionality reduction or feature extraction.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse basis with span: a set of vectors can span the space without being a basis.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Basis and Dimension
contentHtml:
A basis in a vector space is a set of vectors that can be combined to form any other vector in the space.

Think of it like a coordinate system: you need a set of axes (vectors) to define where each point lies. In this case, the points are the vectors themselves!
intuition: The key insight is that a basis provides a way to represent any vector as a linear combination of the basis vectors. This allows us to work with vectors in a more manageable way.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, we often need to transform data into a lower-dimensional space (e.g., PCA) or find a suitable basis for feature extraction (e.g., Fourier transform).
commonMistakes: Don't confuse the concept of a basis with that of an orthonormal set. A basis can have non-orthogonal vectors, whereas an orthonormal set requires both orthogonality and normalization.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Basis and Dimension
contentHtml:
A vector space is a set of vectors with certain operations (addition and scalar multiplication) that satisfy specific properties.

A basis for a vector space is a set of vectors that span the entire space, meaning any vector in the space can be expressed as a linear combination of these basis vectors.
intuition: Think of a vector space like a room filled with different colored blocks. A basis is like a set of specific block combinations that can be used to build any structure (vector) in the room.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, we often work with high-dimensional spaces where finding an efficient basis (e.g., principal components) is crucial for dimensionality reduction and feature extraction.
commonMistakes: Don't confuse a basis with a spanning set; a basis must be linearly independent.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Dimension Theorem
contentHtml:
The Dimension Theorem states that every vector space has a basis.

This means that we can always find a set of vectors that span the entire space and are linearly independent.

theorem.statement: \[\text{Every vector space } V \text{ has a basis.}\]

intuition: This theorem is important because it allows us to work with vectors in a more manageable way. By finding a basis for a vector space, we can represent any vector as a linear combination of the basis vectors.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, this theorem has applications in feature selection and dimensionality reduction.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Find a basis for the subspace V = {(1, 0), (0, 1)} in ℝ².
hints: A basis is a set of vectors that span the subspace and are linearly independent.
You can start by finding two linearly independent vectors in V.
Then, check if these vectors form a spanning set for V.
solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we first observe that {(1, 0), (0, 1)} are linearly independent.

We can verify this by checking the determinant:

\[\det \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = 1 \neq 0.\]

Next, we show that {(1, 0), (0, 1)} span V.

We can write any vector in V as a linear combination of the basis vectors:

\[c_1(1, 0) + c_2(0, 1) = (c_1, c_2).\]

This shows that {(1, 0), (0, 1)} is a basis for V.

",

statementHtml:
Find a basis for the subspace spanned by the vectors \(\mathbf{v}_1 = (1, 2), \mathbf{v}_2 = (3, -1)\) in \(\mathbb{R}^2\).

",
hints:
[ "

Think about what it means for a set of vectors to span a subspace.

", "

You can use the standard basis \((1, 0), (0, 1)\) as a starting point.

", "

Try to find a combination of \(\mathbf{v}_1\) and \(\mathbf{v}_2\) that equals one of the standard basis vectors.

" ],
solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we can start by writing down all possible linear combinations of \(\mathbf{v}_1\) and \(\mathbf{v}_2\):

  • \(\mathbf{0} = c_1 \mathbf{v}_1 + c_2 \mathbf{v}_2\)

Substituting in the values of \(\mathbf{v}_1\) and \(\mathbf{v}_2\), we get:

  • \((c_1, 2c_1 + c_2) = (0, 0)\)

This is equivalent to the system:

  • \(c_1 = 0\)
  • \(2c_1 + c_2 = 0\)

Solving this system, we find that \(c_1 = 0\) and \(c_2 = 0\), so \(\mathbf{v}_1 = (1, 2)\) is a basis vector.

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Find a basis for the subspace of ℝ² spanned by \(\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}\) and \(\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\end{bmatrix}\).

",
hints: Use the span property to find a basis for the subspace.
Check that your basis is linearly independent and spans the subspace.
solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we start with the standard basis \(\{\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\}\). We then use the span property to see that

\(\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\end{bmatrix}\) = 1⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}\) + 2⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\),

\(\begin{bmatrix}3\\4\end{bmatrix}\) = 3⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}\) + 4⋅\(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\).

This shows that the standard basis spans the subspace, so it is a basis.

",

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Find a basis for the subspace \mathbb{W} = \{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^3 : x_1 + 2x_2 - x_3 = 0\}.",
hints: Check if you can find a basis by inspection.
If not, try to find two linearly independent vectors in \mathbb{W}.
Use the fact that any subspace is spanned by its basis.
solutionHtml:
To find a basis for \\mathbb{W}, first notice that \mathbf{x}_1 = (1, 0, -2) and \\mathbf{x}_2 = (2, 1, 0) are both in \\mathbb{W}. Since they're linearly independent, we can take them as a basis.

We can verify that any vector in \\mathbb{W} is spanned by these two vectors:

\mathbf{x} = (x_1, x_2, x_3) \in \\mathbb{W} \Rightarrow x_1 + 2x_2 - x_3 = 0

\\Rightarrow \\mathbf{x} = c_1 \\mathbf{x}_1 + c_2 \\mathbf{x}_2, c_1, c_2 \in \\mathbb{R}.

",
answerShort: A basis for \\mathbb{W} is \\{\mathbf{x}_1, \\mathbf{x}_2\}" },

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding a Basis
contentHtml: A basis of a vector space is a set of vectors that span the entire space and are linearly independent.

problem.statementHtml: Find a basis for the vector space spanned by the vectors \[\mathbf{a} = (1, 2), \mathbf{b} = (3, -1), \mathbf{c} = (-1, 0)\].
hints: Hint: Check if any of the given vectors are linearly independent
problem.solutionHtml:
To find a basis, we first check which vectors are linearly independent. We can do this by calculating their determinants:

  • \[\det(\mathbf{a}) = 1 \cdot 2 - 2 \cdot 1 = 0\]
  • \[\det(\mathbf{b}) = 3 \cdot (-1) + (-1) \cdot 1 = -4 eq 0\]

Since \mathbf{b} is linearly independent, we can choose it as one of our basis vectors. We then check which other vectors are linearly independent with \mathbf{b}:

  • \[\det(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}) = 1 \cdot (-1) + 2 \cdot 3 - 2 \cdot (-1) = 7 eq 0\]

We can choose \mathbf{a} as our second basis vector. Finally, we check which other vectors are linearly independent with both \mathbf{b} and \mathbf{a}:

  • \[\det(\mathbf{c}, \mathbf{b}) = (-1) \cdot (-1) + 0 \cdot 3 - 0 \cdot (-1) = 1 eq 0\]

We can choose \mathbf{c} as our third basis vector. Therefore, the basis is \[\mathbf{B} = \left\{ \mathbf{b}, \mathbf{a}, \mathbf{c} ight\}\].

subject: linear_algebra
title: Finding Bases and Dimension
contentHtml:
In linear algebra, a basis is a set of vectors that spans the vector space.

  • A basis must be linearly independent, meaning one vector cannot be expressed as a combination of the others.
  • A basis must also span the entire vector space, meaning any vector in the space can be written as a linear combination of the basis vectors.
